Complete Blood Count (CBC): Leukopenia (low white blood cell count), anemia (low red blood cell count), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) due to bone marrow suppression.
Liver Function Tests (ALT, AST, ALP, Bil: Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels, indicating hepatotoxicity.
Renal Function Tests (Creatinine, BUN): Elevated levels in cases of renal dysfunction, particularly if combined with other nephrotoxic agents.
Serum Amylase and Lipase: Elevated levels indicating potential drug-induced pancreatitis.
Thiopurine Methyltransferase (TPMT) Acti: Low or absent TPMT activity increases the risk of severe myelosuppression.
Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV): Elevated MCV, often seen with chronic azathioprine use.
C-Reactive Protein (CRP): May decrease due to immunosuppressive effects, though variable based on the condition being treated.
Uric Acid: Elevated levels due to increased cell turnover or reduced renal excretion.
Immunoglobulin Levels (IgG, IgA, IgM): Potentially reduced due to immunosuppressive effects.
Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR): Variable changes; may decrease due to suppression of inflammation.
Peripheral Blood Smear: Macrocytosis (large red blood cells) or cytopenias (low blood cell counts) may be observed.
Serum LDH: Elevated levels, particularly in the context of hemolysis or cellular turnover.
Direct Antiglobulin Test (DAT/Coombs Tes: Positive result in cases of drug-induced hemolytic anemia.
Thioguanine Nucleotide (TGN) Levels: Elevated levels can indicate toxicity due to metabolism of azathioprine.
